etymologies: early 17th century: from late Latin vulnerabilis, from Latin vulnerare ‘to wound’, from vulnus ‘wound’

definitions: susceptible to physical or emotional attack or harm

examples.text: we were in a vulnerable position
small fish are vulnerable to predators

shortDefinitions: exposed to possibility of being attacked or harmed, either physically or emotionally

definitions: (of a person) in need of special care, support, or protection because of age, disability, or risk of abuse or neglect

examples.text: employees must be better trained in how to deal with vulnerable young people

shortDefinitions: in need of special care, support, or protection because of age, disability, etc.

definitions: (of a partnership) liable to higher penalties, either by convention or through having won one game toward a rubber

examples.text: the authors advise a variable no-trump opening bid which means weak non-vulnerable and strong vulnerable

shortDefinitions: (of partnership) liable to higher penalties, either by convention or through having won one game towards rubber
